data.title: Less disk IO
data.body:
Partly fixes #11214.

The biggest problem was that calling `repo.workdir()` on the main thread involved acquiring a lock, which could already be held by a background thread doing disk IO. And on network filesystems, that IO was really expensive, which meant the lock would be held for a looooooong time. See also https://github.com/nodegit/nodegit/pull/968 which removes the need for `repo.workdir()` and friends to acquire the lock.

There are a couple other cases that we found where a lock could be acquired on the main thread:
- [x] `repo.path()`
- [x] `Git.Ignore.pathIsIgnored` (https://github.com/nodegit/nodegit/pull/970)

Even with these changes, performance will still be worse than 1.5.4 because both `GitRepository` and `GitRepositoryAsync` are refreshing their status from git which requires a lot of IO—where in 1.5.4 we only had `GitRepository`.

Ideally `GitRepository` would only do work if some package is using it. Currently that’ll always be the case as `tree-view` hasn’t been updated to use `GitRepositoryAsync` yet (see https://github.com/atom/tree-view/pull/624). But once `tree-view` is updated, that would be a good optimization to do as well.

/cc @nathansobo

data.title: Autocomplete+ does not make it easy to select what you typed as correct
data.body:
I am frequently frustrated by the corrections that autocomplete+ makes as I type, but it is very useful to have _suggestions_. It would help a lot to make the default correction be the string that was typed instead of having to press escape or several arrow keys every time to force autocmplete+ to not change it.

This frequently manifests when I'm typing a string that appears as a substring in other strings in the same project. (e.g.: I type 'us-west-1', and autocomplete wants to change it to 'us-west-1a' or 'us-west-1b' but 'us-west-1' is not an option easily selected in the suggestions menu).

I think what I'm asking for is an option to have autocomplete automatically pop up, but not automatically change anything unless I ask it to.

I am using Atom 1.4.3.

data.title: Add manual pages for Atom and APM
data.body:
Every time, I get bitten by this:

```
$ man atom
No manual entry for atom
$ atom --help
Atom Editor v1.6.0

Usage: atom [options] [path ...]
⋮
```

Same with `apm`. For Unix-like systems, a manual page should be included to supply this information, even if it's ultimately just copying what's available with the `--help` switch.

data.title: Relative position atom-workspace-axis
data.body:
This let's packages use `position: absolute` and be contained to `atom-workspace-axis` elements.

It fixes https://github.com/thomaslindstrom/color-picker/pull/176 where color-picker relied on `background-tips` to add `position: relative;`, but broke when `background-tips` got disabled.

![color-picker](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/14036216/14294b1e-f27a-11e5-8e10-a1dafb6ab570.gif)

:warning: Since `background-tips` only styled `atom-workspace .horizontal .vertical { position: relative; }`, there is a chance that some packages rely `atom-workspace-axis.horizontal` to be `position: static;`. So something to keep an eye on.

data.title: Unable to scroll when mouse is over autocompletion bubble
data.body:
When mouse is over autocompletion bubble it is impossible to scroll.

Version : 1.6.0
OS : OS X 10.11

data.title: JavaScript autocompletion breaking at accent
data.body: When I type in JavaScript there is always autocompletion for word that are not functions or variables. These are useful but as I am a French speaker, I frequently use accents in strings. What happens is the word is cut just before the letter with the accent (e.g. numéro -> num). Sorry if I'm not in the right place but didn't know in what package to put it.

data.title: Fix typo in error message.
data.body: I was just reading the source code and noticed this minor cut-and-paste error in the error message.

data.title: Windows only: Atom command-line throws `find: `ParentProcessId': No such file or directory` error.
data.body:
### Description

Windows only: Atom command-line throws `find:`ParentProcessId': No such file or directory` error.
### Steps to Reproduce

This bug only shows up on Windows. It works as expected on Mac and Linux.
We reproduced this on a Windows 8.1 box.
1. From the command line, run atom with any switches, e.g. `atom -v`.

**Expected behavior:**
Version string, e.g. `1.6.0`

**Actual behavior:**

```
atom -v
```

```
find: `ParentProcessId': No such file or directory
'ELSE' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.

1.6.0
```
### Versions

Atom 1.6.0.
This doesn't happen in Atom 1.5.4.

data.title: Atom crashes when attempting to step into Atom code without the Atom source repository available
data.body:
### Description

Atom crashes when setting breakpoints in my package.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Set breakpoint in package code, wait for it to be hit
2. Step in or over the code
3. Atom crashes

**Expected behavior:** 
I expect atom to allow me to step through the code and be able to debug it.

**Actual behavior:**
Atom crashes every time.
### Versions

1.6.0
### Temporary fix

I've discussed the issue [here](https://discuss.atom.io/t/setting-breakpoints-crashes-atom/27060) , and @lee-dohm suggested I clone the atom repo in `~/github/atom`. After doing that, I'm able to use breakpoints without atom crashing.

data.title: Soft Wrap doesn't respect word boundaries
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

I'm using Atom to write HTML emails (yay). These include long URLs, so I have Soft Wrap turned on.

![soft-wrap](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5524469/14026882/f29a84a2-f1c2-11e5-9d48-b918985b3407.png)

Note how the line gets broken in the middle of the word "Final". There are lots of better places for a line break.

When I go into my Settings, there's an input box for "Non Word Characters"; these characters define word boundaries. It seems to me that it would make sense for Soft Wrap to break lines at word boundaries instead of only at spaces.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Enable Soft Wrap (in the View menu)
2. Write a line of text that exceeds the width of the buffer, thus triggering soft wrap. The line should include some of the Non Word Characters: `/\()"':,.;<>~!@#$%^&*|+=[]{}?-`

**Expected behavior:** Line wraps at a word boundary.

**Actual behavior:** Lines wrap only at spaces.
### Versions

1.6.0

data.title: Fixed selection.copy, which caused bugs in selection.insertText when pasting
data.body:
Referenced Issues: [1](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/9045) [2](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/5473) [3](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/4461) 

In the specific case where you copy text beginning with a newline, the metadata field 'indentBasis' can be improperly stored, which doesn't create any issues until you try to paste somewhere else and the 'autoIndentOnPaste'  setting is on. It uses that incorrect indentBasis which results in incorrect indentation.
### evidence for the bug

1) Take a build of atom besides this one, and make a new file. add the following text:

```
one
  two
```

2) Add `\n\ttwo` to your clipboard by clicking and dragging from the right of 'two' until the right on 'one'. It's important that you capture that newline character.

3) With your cursor to the right of 'two', press cmd+v or ctrl+v depending on your OS. You should have had  the twos at the same indentation level, but instead the second two will be indented twice.

4) If you're not convinced yet, you can try this again with the first 'two' indented twice, and you'll see the second one indented four times.
### What Happens

copy() takes the indent level of the first selected line and stores that as the indentBasis. The user will want an indentBasis of 1, but get an indentBasis of 0 because \n is technically on the previous line.
### Why this matters

When people copy/paste large bodies of text, they will often drag their cursor up and to the right of whatever they're copying, which will give them that initial newline character. Knowing to avoid this is a workaround people shouldn't have to consider when they're focused on writing whatever they're writing.

data.title: fix link in ISSUE_TEMPLATE
data.body: Some link in issue template were dead (it was linked to the manual main page). This PR fixes that.

data.title: Cpp bracket folding problem with directive(s)
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Perhaps still related to #8724 or #11179. It seems the folding brackets in atom still not perfect yet. I have .cpp code : 

``` c++
void send_request(int seq, char* a, int i)
{
    if (seq >= 0) a["seq"] = seq;
    int size = bencode(msg_buf, e);
#if defined DEBUG && IOSTREAM
    std::cerr << "sending: " <<  e << "\n";
#endif

    if (i == g_sent_packets.end())
    {
        TEST_ERROR("not responding");
        return;
    }

    g_sent_packets.erase(i);
}
```

Folding the if statement and #if directive is correct (or at least what I really expected). But folding the class is wrong.

Below is the screenshot of after-folding code
![screenshot from 2016-03-24 17 51 25](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2739025/14024369/09e070a6-f1e9-11e5-96bb-02754032ebb7.png)

I'm not sure if this happened because I put the directive inside the function. Some other function without directives just fold fine.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open Atom (both in safe mode or not still produces same bug)
2. Open the file
3. Fold line 2
4. Bug happens

**Expected behavior:** [What you expected to happen]
The folding should cover line 2-16

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happened]
The folding only covers line 2-5
### Versions

1.6.0

data.title: Atom 1.6 opens wrong computer's windows
data.body:
I use Atom on my laptop and home computer and since installing 1.6 I now always have my laptop folders trying to load when I open Atom on my home computer. No other changes were made (to my knowledge).
### Prerequisites
- none
### Description

Starting Atom opens previous windows but with desktop this now the previous windows from my laptop (which has a completely separate paths to projects). 
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Start Atom on computer 1
2. Start Atom on computer 2
### Versions

```
 atom 1.6.0
 apm  1.6.0
 npm  2.13.3
 node 0.10.40
 python 2.7.11
 git 2.6.4
```

data.title: Power saving mode?
data.body:
I wanted to ask if a power saving mode for Atom is on the roadmap for future releases. 
Power saving mode would turn off many battery intensive feature like background update checks, package update checks, animations and more for the time while it is on.

This would be very helpful if you are running out of battery and really want to squeeze that last extra juice out of your battery and finish writing your code etc.

Thank you all so very much
Cheers!

data.title: OS X > Control-click/right-click in code editor: Package menu items should be sorted in alphabetical order.
data.body:
OS X > Control-click/right-click in code editor: 
Package menu items should be sorted in descending alphabetical order. Currently, they are based on order of installation. 

Thank you!
:)

data.title: Atom not respecting Electron CLI switches
data.body:
This is a follow on from [a discussion in Atom's Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/t/atom-and-electron-cli-switches)

I'm using Atom 1.6, which is built on Electron 0.34.5. In the [Electron docs](https://github.com/atom/electron/blob/v0.34.5/docs/tutorial/debugging-main-process.md) it mentions the `--debug` and `--debug-brk` switches.

Running `/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom --debug-brk=60131` hangs. Normally node processes print out that they're waiting for a listener before proceeding. Using `--debug` allows Atom to run, but as I'm running a test (`--dev --test`) I'd like the process to block so I can connect my debugger.

There may be other Electron switches that Atom also doesn't respect that I don't know of.

data.title: The context of the "Default encoding" should be "new files" with another setting for opening files.
data.body:
There are several issues and comments regarding encoding behavior (atom: #4141, #4160, #10052, #10939, encoding-selector: https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector/issues/8, https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector/issues/24) in Atom, but they all seem to miss the mark.

I imagine that everybody would agree on the following use cases:
1. When the user opens a file, it is opened with the correct encoding.
2. When the user creates a new file and saves it, it is saved with the correct encoding.

These are two separate use cases. "auto-detect" encoding is not applicable to creating new files. I am not familiar with the dependencies and relation between core and encoding-selector (I don't know if encoding-selector can intercept an "open file"?), but here is a possible solution from a use case perspective:
- For opening files, **always** try to auto-detect encoding.
- The user sets his or her **preferred encoding**. The preferred encoding is used when creating **new files**.
- The user sets a **fallback encoding**. Fallback encoding is used when **Opening a file** and **auto-detect fails**.

Using the term _"default encoding"_ is bad in this case since it is ambiguous.

_Edit 2016-05-10_: Suggestions for more clear terms are:
- "default encoding for new files" (a bit long)
- "new file encoding"
- "encoding for new files"
- "default new file encoding"

data.title: Could not connect to indexedDB
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?

data.title: Atom does not use multiple tabs anymore
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

Atom just updated to v1.6.0 - and now it won't open multiple files in multiple tabs anymore.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Start Atom and Open a folder with multiple files.
2. Open a File by clicking on it in the file browser.
3. Open another file by clicking on it in the file browser.

**Expected behavior:** The window should have two tabs with two open files.

**Actual behavior:** After the first click a tab is opened. The tab header is showing the filename in italics. When I click on another file the tab is replaced by the second file. It won't open a second tab anymore.
### Versions

1.6.0

data.title: Fallback to ~/.atom/storage when no state is found in IndexedDb
data.body:
This PR addresses the concerns raised by @jeancroy  in https://github.com/atom/atom/pull/10605#issuecomment-199603786 by falling back to reading state from the storage folder when we can't find one under IndexedDb.

Moreover, this introduces a `clear()` method on `StorageFolder` that deletes the storage folder whenever the user supplies the `--clear-window-state` argument (so that no state can be loaded in both IndexedDb and `~/.atom/storage`).

/cc: @nathansobo @kuychaco @iolsen

data.title: Hide atom-overlay when not visible
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#check-if-the-problem-shows-up-in-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](https://atom.io/docs/latest/hacking-atom-debugging)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

This issue came up [here](https://github.com/atom/one-dark-ui/pull/127).

Currently `atom-overlay`s overlap the rest of the UI. I think it's ok, but only as long as the current line is visible. If you scroll it "out of sight", it looks odd having the overlay still be shown.

A possible solution might be to try to detect when the current line is not visible and then hide the `atom-overlay`. I think autocomplete kinda already tries to do that by jumping to the top when scrolling down, but doesn't hide completely. And would be nice if it's part of the core behavior, so all packages would get it. Maybe with an option to opt-out if a package wants stay visible all the time.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open find + replace `cmd-f`
2. Have autocomplete enabled and type something to open the autocomplete overlay.
3. Scroll down until the current line is underneath the find + replace panel

**Expected behavior:**

The autocomplete overlay should disappear

![overlay](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/13974127/810694a6-f0ec-11e5-897b-f80c7d7fbb52.gif)

**Actual behavior:**

It stays on top of the find + replace panel, even tough you can't see the current line anymore

![screen shot 2016-03-23 at 11 47 53 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/378023/13974215/2793be34-f0ed-11e5-8209-8bd9754f4e6a.png)
### Versions

You can get this information from executing `atom --version` and `apm --version` at the command line.

```
Atom    : 1.8.0-dev-64308bb
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1

apm  1.9.1
npm  2.13.3
node 0.10.40
python 2.7.10
git 2.6.3
```
